newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Canberra confident will pass ASX demutualisation.
newsitem.headline: Canberra confident will pass ASX demutualisation.

text.p: The Australian government was confident it would pass legislation in time to allow the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) to demutualise and publicly list on schedule, a spokesman said on Tuesday.
A meeting of Liberal-National coalition parliamentarians on Tuesday approved legislation removing any Federal impediments to the move, a party spokesman told reporters.

Parliament begins its winter break next week. But the legislation will be introduced and debated in the next session, beginning in August, a spokeswoman for Ian Campbell, the parliamentary secretary to the Treasurer, told Reuters.
The exchange plans to demutualise from January 1, 1998.
"We are still hopeful of meeting that timetable," Campbell's spokeswoman said.
Exchange members in October approved the demutualisation, in a move which would clear the way for the exchange to become the first publicly-listed stock exchange in the world.
The planned legislation also limits individual holdings to a maximum five percent of the exchange's stock.
